choices.text: Increased mobilization of free fatty acids from adipocytes
Decreased acetyl CoA entering the TCA cycle

questions.text: Ketosis is common in Type 1 DM due to all except:
questions.solution:
During ketosis in type 1 DM, metabolic changes leading to

Option A: increased beta oxidation of fatty acids, not decreased.

Option B: Increased mobilization of free fatty acids from adipocytes

Option C: Decreased acetyl CoA entering the TCA cycle due to lack of oxaloacetate.

A fall in the concentration of oxaloacetate, particularly within the mitochondria, can impair the ability of the citric acid cycle to metabolize acetyl-CoA and divert fatty acid oxidation toward ketogenesis. Such a fall may occur because of an increase in the (NADH)/(NAD+) ratio caused when increased β-oxidation alters the equilibrium between oxaloacetate and malate so that the concentration of oxaloacetate is decreased, and also when gluconeogenesis is elevated due to low blood glucose levels. The activation by acetyl-CoA of pyruvate carboxylase, which catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, partially alleviates this problem, but in conditions such as starvation and untreated diabetes mellitus, ketone bodies are overproduced and cause ketosis.

Option D: Increased synthesis of β hydroxybutyrate by ketogenesis

DIABETIC KETOACIDOSIS (DKA)

This condition is caused by increased fatty acid metabolism and the accumulation of ketoacids (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate).

DKA usually occurs in insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus in association with cessation of insulin or an intercurrent illness such as an infection, gastroenteritis, pancreatitis, or myocardial infarction, which increases insulin requirements temporarily and acutely, and is characterized by hyperglycemia, ketonemia, and a high-AG acidosis.

In poorly controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus, patients may become hyperglycemic, both as a result of lack of insulin to stimulate uptake and utilization of glucose, and because in the absence of insulin to antagonize the actions of glucagon, there is increased gluconeogenesis from amino acids in the liver. At the same time, the lack of insulin to antagonize the actions of glucagon results in increased lipolysis in adipose tissue, and the resultant nonesterified fatty acids are substrates for ketogenesis in the liver. Utilization of the ketone bodies in muscle (and other tissues) may be impaired because of the lack of oxaloacetate (all tissues have a requirement for some glucose metabolism to maintain an adequate amount of oxaloacetate for citric acid cycle activity). In uncontrolled diabetes, the ketosis may be severe enough to result in pronounced acidosis (ketoacidosis); acetoacetate and 3-hydroxybutyrate are relatively strong acids. Coma results from both the acidosis and also the considerably increased osmolality of extracellular fluid (mainly as a result of the hyperglycemia, and diuresis resulting from the excretion of glucose and ketone bodies in the urine).

questions.text: DNA methylation is not related to?
questions.solution:
DNA methylation is a process in which a methyl group is added to the cytosine base in DNA. This process can affect gene expression, but it is not directly related to capping.

Capping is a process in which a guanine nucleotide is added to the 5' end of an mRNA molecule. This process helps to protect the mRNA molecule from degradation and helps to ensure that it is translated correctly.

The other options are all related to DNA methylation:

  • Mismatch repair is a process that corrects errors in DNA replication. DNA methylation can affect mismatch repair by preventing the repair machinery from accessing methylated DNA.
  • DNA replication is the process of making a copy of DNA. DNA methylation can affect DNA replication by affecting the binding of DNA replication proteins to DNA.
  • Gene silencing is the process of turning off gene expression. DNA methylation can silence genes by preventing the binding of transcription factors to DNA.

questions.text: Enzymes present in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Glycolysis & Gluconeogenesis share the same pathway but in opposite directions, except irreversible steps of glycolysis catalyzed by different enzymes in gluconeogenesis.

3 irreversible steps of glycolysis are: Step 1: Glucokinase or Hexokinase, Step 3: Phosphofructokinase, Step 10: Pyruvate kinase

Above three irreversible steps in glycolysis are catalyzed by 4 different enzymes in gluconeogenesis. Pyruvate carboxylase & Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (reverse step 10), Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase (reverse step 3), Glucose-6-phosphatase (step 1)

Option A: PFK (Phosphofructokinase) involved in glycolysis only.

Option B: PEP – CK (Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase) involved in gluconeogenesis only.

Option C: Phosphoglycerate kinase present in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

Option D: Pyruvate kinase involved in glycolysis only.

choices.text: Can be reduced from multiple branches/ends
Can be stored at multiple sites
Can provide glucose as much as needed and when needed for 1 week.

questions.text: Glucose is stored in glycogen form, why?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glycogen is the storage polysaccharide in animals and is sometimes called animal starch. It is a more highly branched structure than amylopectin, with chains of 12 to 15 α-d glucopyranose residues (in α1 → 4 glycosidic linkage) with branching by means of α1 → 6 glycosidic bonds making it a compact structure and insoluble

Option B: Glycogen is non reducing sugar.

Option C: It occurs mainly in the liver and muscle, with modest amounts in the brain. Although the liver content of glycogen is greater than that of muscle, because the muscle mass of the body is considerably greater than that of the liver, about three-quarters of total body glycogen is in muscle.

Option D: Liver glycogen functions as a reserve to maintain the blood glucose concentration in the fasting state. The liver concentration of glycogen maintains blood glucose level for 12 to 18 hours (not for week). After 12 to 18 hours of fasting, liver glycogen is almost totally depleted.

Although muscle glycogen does not directly yield free glucose (because muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase), pyruvate formed by glycolysis in muscle can undergo transamination to alanine, which is exported from muscle and used for gluconeogenesis in the liver.

questions.text: Identify the given image
questions.solution:
GAGs (Glycosaminoglycans or mucopolysaccharides) are long, unbranched, heteropolysaccharide chains composed of a repeating disaccharide unit [acidic sugar–amino sugar]n. [Note: A single exception is keratan sulfate, which contains galactose rather than an acidic sugar.] The amino sugar is either D-glucosamine or D-galactosamine, in which the amino group is usually acetylated, thus eliminating its positive charge. The amino sugar may also be sulfated on carbon 4 or 6 or on a nonacetylated nitrogen. The acidic sugar is either D-glucuronic acid or its C-5 epimer L-iduronic acid.

Option D: Above structure showing repeating disaccharide unit made up of D glucuronic acid with N acetyl galactose amine, suggestive structure of chondroitin sulphate.

Option A: Keratan sulphate is made up of repeating disaccharide unit of N acetyl glucosamine and galactose (no uronic acid)

Option B: Dermatan sulphate is made up of a repeating disaccharide unit of L iduronic acid with N acetyl galactose amine.

Option C: Heparin is made up of a repeating disaccharide unit of glucosamine and glucuronic acid or iduronic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis?
questions.solution:
Option A, Option C & Option D: Thiolase, HMG COA synthetase & HMG COA reductase enzymes are involved in synthesis of cholesterol. HMG COA reductase is a key enzyme of cholesterol biosynthesis.

This mevalonate latter forms cholesterol.

Option B: HMG CoA lyase involved in ketone body formation (Ketogenesis).

questions.text: Ammonia is detoxified in the brain, by leading to formation of?
questions.solution:
Option A: Formation of glutamine in the brain is catalyzed by mitochondrial glutamine synthetase. Since amide bond synthesis is coupled to the hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi , the reaction strongly favors glutamine synthesis. During catalysis, glutamate attacks the γ-phosphoryl group of ATP, forming γ-glutamyl phosphate and ADP. Following deprotonation of NH4 +, NH3 attacks γ-glutamyl phosphate, and glutamine and Pi are released. In addition to providing glutamine to serve as a carrier of nitrogen, carbon and energy between organs, glutamine synthetase plays a major role both in ammonia detoxification and in acid–base homeostasis.

Option B: In liver ammonia finally converted into Urea.

Option C: Alanine is involved in the Glucose-alanine cycle. Alanine is synthesized in muscle by transamination of glucose-derived pyruvate, released into the bloodstream, and taken up by the liver. In the liver, the carbon skeleton of alanine is reconverted to glucose and released into the bloodstream, where it is available for uptake by muscle and resynthesis of alanine.

Option D: Arginine is not involved in ammonia detoxification in the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following will be incorrect in Rh incompatibility
questions.solution:
Rh incompatibility occurs when an Rh+ fetus is carried by an Rh− mother, leading to severe hemolytic anemia. In hemolytic anemia,

Option A: Increased unconjugated bilirubin in blood

Option B: Increased stool urobilinogen

Option C: Increased urine urobilinogen

Option D: Absent urine urobilin

questions.text: DNA methylation is not related with?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mismatch repair will repair replication error. Require Mut S, Mut L & Mut H proteins & Specific Endonuclease. It identify newly synthesized strand first (template strand has methylated adenine in -GATC- sequences, new strand is non methylated initially), Identify wrong base in new strand & make a loop, Cut defective strand at site nearing complementary sequence of –GATC-, Gap is filled by DNAP I & ligase, Meanwhile Exonuclease then digest defective strand with wrong base

So it requires DNA methylation.

Option B: DNA replication

Option C: Gene silencing is the regulation of gene expression in a cell to prevent the expression of a certain gene. The predominant mechanism of gene silencing involves the methylation of DNA and subsequent recruitment of various binding proteins that preferably recognize methylated DNA.

Option D: Addition of 5’ Capping does not require DNA methylation. Cap is made up of 7-methylguanylate, attached by unusual 5’-5’ triphosphate bond to ribose, Addition of GTP by enzyme is Guanylyl transferase, then N7 Nitrogen of guanine is methylated by Guanine n7-methyltransferase, SAM is methyl group donor.

choices.text: Total number of times a cell can divide in its lifetime in vivo
Total number of progenies a stem cell can make
Total number of times a cell can divide in cell culture
Total number of times a cancer cell can divide

questions.solution:
In cell culture, this number of divisions is called the Hayflick limit, and cells that cannot undergo further division are said to have entered a phase of replicative cellular senescence. In most cells, after multiple divisions, the telomeres are truncated to a point where cell division cannot continue.

So Option C is the correct answer.

questions.text: Calories from TPN: 100mg dextrose. 30mg amino acids, 40 mg lipids
questions.solution:
Carbohydrates & protein (amino acid) provide energy of 4 Kcal/gm, whereas fats are a concentrated source of energy providing 9 Kcal/gm.

So total calorie calculation = (100 x 4) + (30 x 4) + (40 x 9) = 880

So Option D is correct.

Option B: The main clinical manifestation of pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy is generalized seizures, which usually occur in the first days of life and are unresponsive to conventional anticonvulsant therapies. Some mothers of affected fetuses report abnormal intrauterine fluttering movements. The seizures are usually tonic-clonic in nature but can be almost any type. Other manifestations such as dystonia, respiratory distress, and abdominal distention with vomiting, hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia and hypothermia may be present. Learning problems and speech delay are common sequelae. Late-onset forms of the condition (as late as 5 years of age) have been reported. Consequently, a trial with vitamin B6 is recommended in any infant with intractable convulsions

Option A, Option C & Option D:  Thiamine, Riboflavin & Pantothenic acid deficiency not reported to cause neonatal seizures.

Vitamin D is synthesized in the skin & then metabolized to the active metabolite, calcitriol, in liver & kidney. So correct sequence of vitamin D synthesis & metabolism is Skin → Liver → Kidney (Option A)

7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in the synthesis of cholesterol that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a non enzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding previtamin D. This undergoes a further reaction over a period of hours to form cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream. In temperate climates, the plasma concentration of vitamin D is highest at the end of summer and lowest at the end of winter. Beyond latitudes about 40° north or south, there is very little ultraviolet radiation of the appropriate wavelength in winter.

Cholecalciferol, either synthesized in the skin or from food, undergoes two hydroxylations to yield the active metabolite, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D or calcitriol. Ergocalciferol from fortified foods undergoes similar hydroxylation yield calcitriol. In the liver, cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to form the 25-hydroxy derivative, calcidiol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin. In the kidney, calcidiol undergoes either 1-hydroxylation to yield the active metabolite 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), or 24-hydroxylation to yield a probably inactive metabolite, 24,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (24-hydroxy calcidiol). Some tissues, other than those that are involved in calcium homeostasis, take up calcidiol from the circulation and synthesize calcitriol that acts within that cell

So Option A is the correct option.

Option A: Competitive inhibition

  • Compete with substrate for attaching with active site
  • Binds to same site on enzyme where substrate binds (active site)
  • Structural analogue of substrate
  • Reversible, excess substrate reduces inhibition
  • Km is increased (affinity is decreased), Vmax is not changed
  • Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase
  • Dicoumarol is also structurally similar to vitamin K, Act as an anticoagulant by competitively inhibiting vitamin K reductase enzyme, so reduced vitamin K activity

Option B: Noncompetitive inhibition

  • No competition between substrate and inhibitor
  • No structural resemblance to substrate
  • Binds to different site on enzyme, other than substrate binding site, but it induce conformational changes in enzyme, so alters shape of active site and prevents binding of substrate
  • Increase in substrate concentration does not relieve this inhibition
  • Km value is not changed, because remaining enzyme molecules have same affinity for substrate
  • Vmax is reduce
  • Many poisons (Heavy metal ions & oxidizing agents) are explained by principle of noncompetitive inhibition
  • Heavy metals like Hg, Ag, Pb etc - will react with SH group of enzyme and inactivate them reversibly
  • Iodoacetate - inhibit enzymes having-SH group in their active centers irreversibly
  • Ascaris (Intestinal worm) produces an inhibitor of enzyme trypsin, so able to survive in the intestine, otherwise trypsin would digest the worm and kill it.
  • BAL (British Anti Lewisite) - Antidote for heavy metal poisoning, BAL has many –SH groups so it is attached with heavy metals and reduces their toxicity.
  • Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase, so reduce ETC and lead to toxicity

Option C: Mechanism-based" or "suicide" inhibitors are specialized substrate analogs that contain a chemical group that can be transformed by the catalytic machinery of the target enzyme. After binding to the active site, catalysis by the enzyme generates a highly reactive group that forms a covalent bond to and blocks the function of a catalytically essential residue.

Allopurinol is oxidized by xanthine oxidase to alloxanthine that is strong inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, so reduce formation of uric acid, Used in treatment of gout

Option D: Uncompetitive inhibition

  • Does not have any affinity for free enzymes
  • Binds to ES complex; but not to free enzyme
  • Both Vmax and Km are decreased
  • Example…Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan Isoenzyme) by phenylalanine

questions.text: Correct about given vacutainer is
questions.solution:
Option A: EDTA ccontaining vacutainer are usually lavender blue in colour. It is commonly used for whole blood/haematology study.

Option B: NaF containing vacutainer is grey in colour and commonly used to measure plasma glucose level. NaF is an antiglycolytic agent. It chelates Mg and inhibits enolase enzyme in glycolysis, so stop glycolysis and prevent reduction of sugar which transporting sample to laboratory. Anticoagulant here in grey container is Potassium oxalate.

Option C: Heparin containing vacutainer is green colour. It is used in estimation of plasma chemistry.

Option D: Red colour vacutainer contain clot activator, used for serum chemistry and serology.

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.text: Which value is not required to measure creatinine clearance?
questions.solution:
Clearance is the volume of plasma from which a compound is completely cleared by the kidney in unit time.

It is calculated by the formula: Clearance (mL/min) = (U × V)/P where U is concentration of the measured analyte in a timed sample of urine (usually 24 hours); P is plasma concentration of the analyte; and V is volume of urine produced per minute (calculated by dividing the volume of urine collected over 24 hours by [24 × 60]).

Option A, Option B & Option D: So as per above formula formula for creatinine measurement, Urine creatinine in 24 hours, Serum creatinine & 24hrs urine volume is used to measure creatinine clearance.

Option C: Volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used.

Measurement of creatinine clearance gives an estimate of the GFR, and so can be used to detect the early stages of renal failure.

A compound that is useful for measurement of renal clearance has a fairly constant blood concentration, is excreted only in urine, is freely filtered at the glomerulus, and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubules.

Although creatinine clearance is commonly measured, it overestimates GFR because it is secreted by the renal tubules to a small extent. Inulin clearance satisfies all the criteria essential for a compound to be used in clearance tests. However, unlike creatinine, inulin is an exogenous compound that has to be infused intravenously at a constant rate.

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotic cells is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Option A: Lysosomes are spherical tiny organelles, containing many lysosomal enzymes which are active at acidic pH. Found in large quantities in neutrophils and macrophages. It helps in Breakdown of large molecules, Digest foreign agent like bacteria & virus (help in phagocytosis)

Option B: Extracellular vesicles (EVs; exosomes and microvesicles) are a group of small vesicles with a lipid bilayer that are released by a wide range of cells, both normal and diseased. These vesicles vary from one another in their size and the way in which they are formed. Collectively, noncoding RNAs (ncRNA) (comprising miRNAs, long noncoding RNAs [lncRNAs], and circular RNAs [circRNAs]; can be loaded into EVs, which are then secreted. Such EV associated ncRNAs have been shown to exert paracrine effects on surrounding cells thereby facilitating intercellular communication. EVs have been shown to transfer information to target cells by mechanisms such as receptor ligand binding, direct fusion of the EV with the plasma membrane of recipient cells, or by endocytosis. Transfer of ncRNAs in this way has been implicated in the pathogenesis of several diseases; cancer is one such condition, where laboratory studies have shown that EVs can modulate expression of crucial genes that are involved in tumorigenesis.

Option C: Peroxisomes are small spherical structures containing granular matrices, prominent in leucocytes & platelets. Their function is to destroy free radicals by enzymes so as to prevent neurodegenerative disease & cancer, Oxidation of VLCFA & Metabolism of glyoxylate (Glycine).

Option D: Microsomes are fragments of the endoplasmic reticulum. It is involved in synthesis, sorting and secretion of protein and other metabolic functions.

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase:
questions.solution:
Option A: Glycogen phosphorylase in muscle activated in response to cytosolic Ca2+ ion concentration.

Option B & Option C: Active glycogen phosphorylase in liver and muscle is allosterically inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate.

Option D: In liver, free glucose is also an inhibitor of glycogen phosphorylase (but not in muscle).

Glycogen phosphorylase catalyzes the rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis, the phosphorolytic cleavage of the α(1→4) linkages of glycogen to yield glucose-1-phosphate and then glucose.

There are different isoenzymes of glycogen phosphorylase in liver, muscle, and brain, encoded by different genes. Glycogen phosphorylase requires pyridoxal phosphate as its coenzyme.

Regulation of Glycogenolysis

1) The principal enzymes controlling glycogen metabolism (Glycogen phosphorylase and glycogen synthase) are regulated in opposite directions by allosteric mechanisms and covalent modification by reversible phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of enzyme in response to hormone action.

Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase increases its activity; phosphorylation of glycogen synthase reduces its activity.

Phosphorylation is increased in response to cyclic AMP (cAMP) formed from ATP by adenylyl cyclase in response to hormones such as epinephrine, norepinephrine, and glucagon. cAMP is hydrolysed by phosphodiesterase in response to hormone insulin, so terminating hormone action; in liver insulin increases the activity of phosphodiesterase.

2) Glycogen phosphorylase regulation is different in liver & muscle. In liver, the role of glycogen is to provide free glucose for export to maintain the blood concentration of glucose; in muscle, the role of glycogen is to provide a source of glucose 6-phosphate for glycolysis in response to the need for ATP for muscle contraction. So In both tissues, the enzyme is activated by phosphorylation catalyzed by phosphorylase kinase and inactivated by dephosphorylation catalyzed by phosphoprotein phosphatase, in response to hormonal and other signals.

Active phosphorylase a in both tissues is allosterically inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate. In liver, free glucose is also an inhibitor (but not in muscle).

3) Glycogenolysis in muscle increases several 100-fold at the onset of contraction; the same signal (increased cytosolic Ca2+ ion concentration) is responsible for initiation of both contraction and glycogenolysis.

Muscle phosphorylase kinase, which activates glycogen phosphorylase, is a tetramer of four different subunits, α, β, γ, and δ. The α and β subunits contain serine residues that are phosphorylated by cAMP-dependent protein kinase. The δ subunit is identical to the Ca2+-binding protein calmodulin and binds four Ca2+. The binding of Ca2+ activates the catalytic site of the γ subunit even while the enzyme is in the dephosphorylated state; the phosphorylated a form is only fully activated in the presence of high concentrations of Ca2+
